narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about what careers in STEM can be outside of academia
Knowledge of different career pathways, exploration of new industry areas.

I learned a bit about the broad possibilities for future careers, graduate school, and other trajectories in biomedical engineering and beyond. I also learned to properly put together a research proposal.
Lots of great guest lecturers and also how to write a proposal
I learned mostly about the BME industry from guest lectures
Most of it was common knowledge but we got to see a lot of perspectives on BME careers which is helpful. Many were in consulting, though.
This course taught us how to write research proposals and come up with ideas for biomedical engineering. We also learned about the many different paths we can take after a BME degree.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course started off poorly because everyone was under the impression we would be attending class once a week given the fact that it was a half credit course and in prior years it only met once a week. We were told from the very beginning they were trying to make it a full credit in the future, but that just left everyone frustrated with the fact that we were doing the work of a full credit course and only getting a half credit for it. We also never received any feedback on any of our final versions of our assignments, which was extremely frustrating. We did have some fantastic speakers throughout the course though and they did try to gear the speakers towards more BME industry related topics, which was nice.
Great speakers, some of the lectures were too long and drawn out though

Andre brought in some wonderful speakers during this course. I wish we had the chance to hear from them earlier in our Yale career. I would also have liked a little more diversity in area of industry that the industry speakers were in; perhaps some SynBio, immunoengineering, etc. but I thought this was pretty well-distributed.

One assignment, I think, would have been an adequate workload for this course as it's a half-credit senior seminar. But I guess labs are a half credit and triple the work. Perhaps we could do weekly discussion forums instead of working on assignments. I didn't feel like the presentation assignment was particularly helpful, as I'd written multitudes of presentations (technical, slide decks, etc) before this class so really didn't benefit from it. I did end up having a good time with the topic, though!

I also think that Andre would talk unnecessarily to fill up the space at the end of the lecture sometimes.

The course had pretty interesting guest lectures and the assignments made sense. The teaching staff was also pretty invested in the course.

That said, a 0.5 credit class should not meet twice a week, like this class did. The course also did not have enough material to fill in all of these meeting times anyway, as during many classes it felt like the professor was purposefully filling/wasting time to ensure that students stayed until the end of the period. Also, there was bad communication on assignment deadlines, especially early on in the semester, where expectations for presentations were explained only a few days before a preliminary deadline (not a huge problem). The diversity/variety of guest speakers was fairly strong and each on their own were very interesting. However, I should mention that there was one or two weeks where every guest basically advocated for the amazing strengths of starting one's career in consulting, and this message just seemed a bit repetitive after some time (especially since this is a BME class).

I absolutely loved the guest lectures. I thought they were interesting and super helpful to me in determining a path after college. However, on some of the days where we did not have a guest lecturer, I felt that we were just meeting for the purpose of meeting, and not to actually learn new information. Some of these days were helpful, but definitely not the majority. I felt this class could easily have met only once a week, especially considering it is only a half of a credit.

Nice to see different perspectives and get practice writing and talking about BME. 
This course should be 1 full credit (weekly hw + two class meetings per week!). We should have all gotten a full credit for this.

This course was good in that we had the chance to work with people in our major and learn from each other's ideas. The weakness of the course was that at times virtual lecture could be a bit dry and not as engaging without more interactive components.

This class was half a credit but met twice a week. It didnt really teach me anything I didnt already know as a senior BME major that hadnt been already covered multiple times in other required classes. Also confused as to why we had such an extensive final paper for a half credit class. Also lectures felt like we all knew there was no substance being taught but we all just had to sit there and let the time run out as we spoke about random BME related topics.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We were able to have some incredible speakers in the course over zoom, which probably would not have been possible prior to the pandemic because of scheduling and travel necessities. However, the extent to which we were told to have our cameras was extremely frustrating, given the fact that some people may be in a virtual learning environment in which they are uncomfortable having their camera on. I think it would have been helpful to find a better way to suggest prior to the first class that people should have their cameras on because even those who may have been granted permission must have been uncomfortable given how often we were told to turn them on.
Half credit course, so should have just met once a week. Also we didn't receive any grades so a bit stressed about that.

We were forced to be on camera and called out if we weren't; I feel like this is a bad practice, in that sometimes I would be squished into my kitchen with my family or need to make food and be PMed about cameras on. This should be relaxed -- it felt kind of invasive to be DM'ed about it. There should be a bit more trust between teachers + students about this!
The class just needed to meet less often, or get a full 1 credit rather than just 0.5.
great online presentations
I really liked having so many virtual speakers from around the world, those were a highlight of the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, good speakers.
You have to take it for BME, but the speakers are really good and the assignments are not too high workload. Nothing that I could use on a portfolio/in a resume, but not a huge ask.

The TA's and Professor all try really hard to make this class great. The speakers are really interesting and the projects are a cool opportunity to work on new projects. However, this class is a requirement that simply should not exist. It doesn't teach you anything useful as a senior (maybe as a first year this class would be great). It also meets 2x per week (unlike the sophomore seminar which met 1x per week) so is a large time commitment.
It's required if you are a BME senior, so yes.
Yes if they are in the BME major
I would recommend this course to all BME seniors as it is a necessary class for all BME students to reflect and think about their projects and futures.
No, this course should be cancelled.
